item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @djzone djzone
item.description:
@djzone wrote:

simply put your command is a load of hocus which will not work because it’s not referring to the actual prayer book :palm: and only sends the user a message…

if (cmd[0].equalsIgnoreCase("togglepray")) {
	player.curses = !player.curses;
	player.getPackets().sendGameMessage(player.curses ? "Prayer book set to curses" : "Prayer book set to normal");
	
}

may need minor changes

Read full topic

item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

It’s an example…
I was trying to demonstrate the code you’re using is wrong… And to use what I literally told you to use…

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:2, topic:549749”]!player.getCombatDefinitions().getPrayBook()
What it does is, is it sets the boolean prayBook (or however it’s named) to the opposite of what it currently is
So if it was false, it’d be set to true. If true, it’d be set to false.[/quote]

So here’s an example… Again…

[code=java]public class AnotherBooleanExample {

private static boolean prayBook = false;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	System.out.println("Boolean is: " + getPrayBook());
	setPrayBook(!getPrayBook());
	System.out.println("Boolean is: " + getPrayBook());
	setPrayBook(!getPrayBook());
	System.out.println("Boolean is: " + getPrayBook());
}

public static boolean getPrayBook() {
	return prayBook;
}

public static void setPrayBook(boolean curse) {
	if(curse)
		System.out.println("Set to curses...");
	else
		System.out.println("Set to normal");
	prayBook = curse;// I noticed you don't have a single line similar to this in your setPrayBook method... You seriously need to add it. Otherwise your shit ain't gonna work right.
}

}[/code]

Boolean is: false                                                                           
Set to curses...                                                                            
Boolean is: true                                                                            
Set to normal                                                                               
Boolean is: false

Read full topic

item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

You don’t need the split…

If you’d use what I said to, your command would be working.

Here’s an example

[code=java]public class BooleanTest {

 public static void main(String[] args) {
      boolean aBoolean = false;
      System.out.println("Boolean is: " + aBoolean);
      aBoolean = !aBoolean;
      System.out.println("Boolean is: " + aBoolean);
      aBoolean = !aBoolean;
      System.out.println("Boolean is: " + aBoolean);
 }

}[/code]

Output:

Boolean is: false; Boolean is: true; Boolean is: false;

Read full topic

item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @mortal4combat mortal4combat
item.description:
@mortal4combat wrote:

here is the command in CombatDefinitions.JAVA

public void setPrayBook(boolean curses) { if (curses == true) { player.getPackets().sendGameMessage("Prayer book set to curses."); } else { player.getPackets().sendGameMessage("Prayer book set to normal prayers."); } }
and here is the command in Commands.JAVA
if (cmd[0].equalsIgnoreCase("togglepray")){ String[] setPrayBook = cmd[0].split(" "); player.getCombatDefinitions().setPrayBook(Boolean.parseBoolean(setPrayBook[1])); player.getPackets().sendGameMessage("Prayer book set to curses."); return true; }
but i receive this message: [img]http://s21.postimg.org/ewdckwj9j/pray.png[/img]

Read full topic

item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

No, because you’re only going to ask me to do everything for you. Which will only put you back where we are now, asking another question about how to do something.

What is the data type for setPrayBook?
You can figure it out by searching the text “setPrayBook” in the windows file search.
It’ll give you a list of files that use it. Find the one that has something along the lines of

Now post the code from the beginning part of it, where it says public void, to the ending brace, which is this thing: }

item.title: PrayBook switch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

You can’t parse the number “2” into a boolean…

Perhaps you meant to put:

If you put the above code in place of the two (Assuming the getter exists) it should work.
What it does is, is it sets the boolean prayBook (or however it’s named) to the opposite of what it currently is
So if it was false, it’d be set to true. If true, it’d be set to false.
